intro: Ophryoscleria sororia, commonly known as the white-veined dandelion, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Asteraceae family and is characterized by its basal rosette of hairy, oval-shaped leaves. The plant produces yellow flowers that develop into white, fluffy seeds, typical of the dandelion genus. Its leaves have prominent white veins, which give it its common name. Ophryoscleria sororia is often found in disturbed soils and is adapted to thrive in open, sunny environments.
